availability.p: The text of the original item is in the public domain. Subject to certain exceptions, public domain works may be freely copied or used in the creation of derivative works without permission, or authorization, of the former copyright owners.
The text encoding was created and/or prepared by the Walt Whitman Archive and is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International License (CC BY 4.0).
Permission to reproduce the graphic images of the original item has been granted by the owners of the original for this publication only.

notesStmt.note:
Early discussions of this notebook dated it in the 1840s, and the date associated with it in the Library of Congress finding aid is 1847. The cover of the notebook features a note calling it the "Earliest and Most Important Notebook of Walt Whitman." A note on leaf 27 recto includes the date April 19, 1847, and the year 1847 is listed again as part of a payment note on leaf 43 recto. More recently, however, scholars have argued that Whitman repurposed this notebook, and that most of the writing was more likely from 1853 to 1854, just before the publication of Leaves of Grass. Almost certainly Whitman began the notebook by keeping accounts, producing the figures that are still visible on some of the page stubs, and later returned to it to write the poetry and prose drafts. For further discussion of dating and the fascinating history of this notebook into the twentieth century, see Matt Miller, Collage of Myself: Walt Whitman and the Making of Leaves of Grass (Lincoln: University of Nebraska Press, 2010), 2–8. See also Andrew C. Higgins, "Wage Slavery and the Composition of Leaves of Grass: The 'Talbot Wilson' Notebook," Walt Whitman Quarterly Review 20:2 (Fall 2002), 53–77; and Floyd Stovall, "Dating Whitman's Early Notebooks," Studies in Bibliography 24 (1971), 197–204.
Scholars have noted a relationship between this notebook and much of the prose and poetry that appeared in the 1855 edition of Leaves of Grass. See, for instance, Edward Grier, Notebooks and Unpublished Prose Manuscripts (New York: New York University Press, 1984), 1:53–82. The notebook was lost when Grier published his transcription (based on microfilm). The notebook features an early (if not the earliest) example of Whitman using his characteristic long poetic lines, as well as the "generic or cosmic or transcendental 'I'" that appears in Leaves of Grass (Grier, 1:55).

bibl.orgName: The Thomas Biggs Harned Collection of the Papers of Walt Whitman, 1842–1937, Library of Congress, Washington, D.C.

note.p: These notes relate loosely to ideas expressed in the 1855 Preface to Leaves of Grass.

The notes on American character relate to ideas expressed in "Song of Myself," most directly to the line "By God! I will accept nothing which all cannot have their counterpart of on the same terms," which is echoed here. All citations of poetry in relations going forward are from the 1891 edition of Leaves of Grass, unless otherwise noted.
This line relates to a poem that first appeared in the 1856 edition of Leaves, that would eventually be titled "Song of Prudence."

div2.note: Be simple and clear.—Be not occult.
div2.p:
True noble expanded American character is raised on a far more lasting and universal basis than that of any of the characters of of the "gentlemen" of aristocratic life, or of novels, or in the European or Asiatic forms of society or government.—It is to be illimitably proud, independent, self-possessed and generous and gentle.—It is to accept nothing except what is equally free and eligible to every body else.—It is to be poor, rather than rich—but to prefer 17
death sooner than any mean dependence.—Prudence is part of it, because prudence is the right arm of independence.
Every American young man should carry himself with the finished and haughty bearing of the greatest ruler and proprietor—for he is the a great ruler and proprietor—th the greatest.
div2.ab: Great latitude must be allowed to others

Bring Play your muscle, and it will be lithe as willow and gutta
caoutchouc and strong as iron—I wish to see American young men the workingmen, carry themselves with a high horse

note.p: This section is similar in sentiment to what would become section 48 in "Song of Myself." See, for instance, the lines: "And nothing, not God, is greater to one than one's self is," and "I hear and behold God in every object, yet understand God not in the least, / Nor do I understand who there can be more wonderful than myself." (1891, p. 76).

This section is similar in wording to the following line in the preface to the 1855 Leaves of Grass: "the air they have of persons who never knew how it felt to stand in the presence of superiors—" (1855, p. iii).

This section also is similar in wording to a line in the Whitman-authored review "Walt Whitman and His Poems," first published in the United States Review: "Every move of him has the free play of the muscle of one who never knew what it was to feel that he stood in the presence of a superior."

div2.p: Where is the being of whom I am the inferior?—It is the of the sly or shallow to divide men like the metals, into those more precious and others less precious, instrinsically

I will not have be the cart, nor the load on the cart, nor the horses that draw the cart; but I will be the little pair of little
hands that guide the cart.—

div2.ab: Ask Mr. Dwight about the highest numeral term known

note.p: The language of this note is similar to that expressed in the poem that would eventually be titled "Song of Myself," including the fifth line: "I lean and loafe at my ease . . . . observing a spear of summer grass." (1855, p. 13).

This note has language and ideas in common with the poem eventually titled "This Compost," which appeared in the 1856 Leaves as "Poem of Wonder at the Resurrection of The Wheat." See, for instance, the line "Though probably every spear of grass rises out / of what was once a catching disease" (1856, p. 204).

The phrase "spear of grass" in this note was used in the Preface to the 1855 edition of Leaves: "any miracle of affairs or persons inadmissible in the vast clear scheme where every motion and every spear of grass and the frames and spirits of men and women and all that concerns them are unspeakably perfect miracles all referring to all and each distinct and in its place" (1855, p. viii).

div2.ab: Different objects which decay, and by the chemistry of nature, their bodies are into spears of grass—

note.p: This note echoes the opening lines of the 1855 Preface to Leaves of Grass.

note.p: This note relates to ideas expressed in "Song of Myself."

div2.ab: Bring all the art and science of the world, and baffle and humble it with one spear of grass

but the dawn of the morning of a nation.—The night has passed and the day appears when people walk abroad—to do evil or to do good

note.p: The following reflections on how "the soul or spirit" transmutes itself are paralleled loosely in the poem that would become "Song of Myself." See in particular sections 13-14. Bradley and Blodgett also note a similarity to lines in section 31.

The following reflections on how "the soul or spirit" transmutes itself are paralleled loosely in the poem that would become "Song of the Answerer:" "The insulter, the prostitute, the angry person, the beggar, see themselves in the ways / of him . . . . he strangely transmutes them" (1855, p. 87).
The following reflections on how "the soul or spirit" transmutes itself are paralleled loosely in "The Sleepers," particularly the image of the whale.
The following reflections relate most directly to the poem eventually titled "There Was a Child Went Forth."
This passage is paralleled loosely in the 1855 Preface to Leaves of Grass (1855, p. iv).

div2.p: The soul or spirit transmutes itself into all matter—into rocks, and cand live the life of a rock—into the sea, and can feel itself the sea—into the oak, or other tree—into an animal, and feel itself a horse, a fish, or a bird—into the earth—into the motions of the suns and stars—

A man only is interested in any thing when he identifies himself with it—he must himself be whirling and speeding through space like the planet
Mercury—he must be driving like a cloud—he must shine like the sun—he must be orbic and balanced in the air, like this earth—he must crawl like the pismire—he must

—he would be growing fragrantly in the air, like a the
locust blossoms—he would rumble and crash like the thunder in the sky—he would spring like a cat on his prey—he would splash like a whale in the

The mean and bandaged soul
spirit
is perpetually dissatisfied with itself—It is too wicked, or too poor, or too feeble
Never speak of the soul as any thing but intrinsically great.—The adjective affixed to it must always testify greatness and immortaliyimmortality and purity.—

note.p: These passages directly echo lines in the poem eventually titled "The Sleepers": "The soul is always beautiful . . . . it appears more or it appears less . . . . it comes or lags behind, / ... / The twisted skull waits . . . . the watery or rotten blood waits, / The child of the glutton or venerealee waits long, and the child of the drunkard waits long, and the drunkard himself waits long," (1855, pp. 75–76).

note.p: This passage is a direct draft of these lines from the poem eventually titled "Song of Myself": "This day before dawn I ascended a hill and look'd at the crowded heaven, / And I said to my spirit When we become the enfolders of those orbs, and the pleasure and knowledge of every thing in them, shall we be fill'd and satisfied then? / And my spirit said No, we but level that lift to pass and continue beyond" (1891, p. 74).

note.p: This passage includes the idea of dilation, a word that also appears in the poem that would be titled "Song of Myself": "I chant a new chant of dilation or pride" (1855, p. 26). See also: "This day before dawn I ascended a hill and looked at the crowded heaven, / And I said to my spirit, When we become the enfolders of those orbs and the pleasure and knowledge of every thing in them, shall we be filled and satisfied then? / And my spirit said No, we level that lift to pass and continue beyond." (1855, p. 52).

note.p: This language is similar to the following line from the poem that would become "Song of Myself": "Seeing hearing and feeling are miracles, and each part and tag of me is a miracle" (1855, p. 29).

note.p: Portions of these passages directly echo lines from "Song of Myself." These passages correspond to all or part of the following lines from the published poem: "I tramp a perpetual journey, / My signs are a rain-proof coat and good shoes and a staff cut from the woods; / No friend of mine takes his ease in my chair, / I have no chair, nor church nor philosophy; / I lead no man to a dinner-table or library or exchange, / But each man and each woman of you I lead upon a knoll, / My left hand hooks you round the waist, / My right hand points to landscapes of continents, and a plain public road. / Not I, not any one else can travel that road for you, / You must travel it for yourself. / It is not far . . . . it is within reach, / Perhaps you have been on it since you were born, and did not know, / Perhaps it is everywhere on water and on land." (1855, pp. 51-2).

note.p: A line in this passage matches the following in the poem that would be titled "Song of Myself": "Not one is dissatisfied . . . . not one is demented with the mania of owning things" (1855, p. 34).

note.p: These phrases from this passage are directly echoed in the poem later titled "Song of Myself": "Washes and razors for foofoos . . . . for me freckles and a bristling beard" (1855, p. 28). This line was dropped from "Song of Myself" in 1881. There are also resonances with other lines from "Song of Myself" in this section, particularly the line: "And nothing, not God, is greater to one than one's-self is" (1855, p. 53).

note.p: This passage is echoed in the following lines from the poem that would be titled "Song of Myself": "The boatmen and clamdiggers arose early and stopped for me, / I tucked my trowser-ends in my boots and went and had a good time, / You should have been with us that day round the chowder-kettle." (1855, p. 18).

note.p: These lines anticipate the following, from the poem that would be titled "Song of Myself": "I am the poet of the body, / And I am the poet of the soul." (1855, p. 26). The phrasing, "I am the poet of _____, and of _____" is echoed in a later line, but slaves and masters become woman and man.

These lines anticipate the reference to slaves and masters in the poem that would be titled "The Sleepers": "The call of the slave is one with the master's call . . and the master salutes the slave," (1855, p. 76).

These lines also may anticipate the following lines in the preface to the 1855 Leaves of Grass: "Little or big, learned or unlearned, white or black, legal or illegal, sick or well, from the first inspiration down the windpipe to the last expiration out of it, all that a male or female does that is vigorous and benevolent and clean is so much sure profit to him or her in the unshakable order of the universe and through the whole scope of it forever. If the savage or felon is wise it is well . . . . if the greatest poet or savan is wise it is simply the same . . if the President or chief justice is wise it is the same . . . if the young mechanic or farmer is wise it is no more or less . . if the prostitute is wise it is no more nor less" (1855, p. x).

note.p: This heavily edited passage shows Whitman thinking through the lines: "To any one dying . . . . thither I speed and twist the knob of the door, / Turn the bedclothes toward the foot of the bed, / Let the physician and the priest go home" through "And when you rise in the morning you will find what I tell you is so" from the poem that would be titled "Song of Myself" (1855, p. 45). Many lines are exactly the same.

note.p: These lines are similar to the following lines in the poem that would eventually be titled "To Think of Time": "The difference between sin and goodness is no apparition; / The earth is not an echo . . . . man and his life and all the things of his life are well-considered" (1855, p. 67).

This line is similar to a line in the poem that would become "Song of Myself": "A word of reality . . . . materialism first and last imbueing" (1855, p. 28). These lines also have words that appear in the following lines found in the poem: "I find I incorporate gneiss and coal and long-threaded moss and fruits and grains and esculent roots," and "In vain the plutonic rocks send their old heat against my approach" (1855, p. 34).

Nor is any
thing man
there any
sham in the universe.
And the world is no joke,
Nor any th part of it a sham,

note.p: This passage contains a line directly related to a line that appears in the poem that would be titled "Song of Myself": "Of fog in the air and beetles rolling balls of dung" (1855, p. 29). This passage also contains seven lines that are a near word-for-word draft of the lines from "Song of Myself" that begin, "I believe a leaf of grass is no less than the journey-work of the stars" (1855, p. 34). Another line is a draft of the following line from the poem: "And mossy scabs of the wormfence, and heaped stones, and elder and mullen and pokeweed" (1855, p. 16). This line also is similar in structure and sentiment to what would become lines in sections 16 and 19 of "Song of Myself" (1891, p. 42–3).

These lines also may anticipate the following lines in the preface to the 1855 Leaves of Grass: "Little or big, learned or unlearned, white or black, legal or illegal, sick or well, from the first inspiration down the windpipe to the last expiration out of it, all that a male or female does that is vigorous and benevolent and clean is so much sure profit to him or her in the unshakable order of the universe and through the whole scope of it forever. If the savage or felon is wise it is well . . . . if the greatest poet or savan is wise it is simply the same . . if the President or chief justice is wise it is the same . . . if the young mechanic or farmer is wise it is no more or less . . if the prostitute is wise it is no more nor less" (1855, p. x).

unlearned

I am the poet of little
things and of babes

is not less than

loose heaped stones and some
elder and poke-weed.
Is picture enough

div2.ab: Amount rec'dreceived from Mr. V. A.

note.p: These seven pages of crossed-out lines contain thinking toward and lines from the poem that would be titled "Song of Myself," specifically the passage that begins: "To be in any form, what is that?" through "Landscapes projected masculine full-sized and golden" (1855, pp. 32–3).

This line relates directly to a line in the poem that would become "Song of Myself": "And a mouse is miracle enough to stagger sextillions of infidels" (1855, p. 34). These lines relate to other lines in the poem: "The press of my foot to the earth springs a hundred affections, / They scorn the best I can do to relate them." (1855, p. 21).

lg.head: I am the poet of Equality.

lg.l:
* And a mouse is miracle
enough to stagger an infidel,
trillions of infidels.

And I cannot put my toe
anywheanywhere to the ground,

But it
shall must touch numberless
and curious books

Each one
above scorning all that
science of schools and
science of the world
can do fully to
read translate them.

note.p: These nine lines are a direct draft of six lines of the poem that would be titled "Song of Myself" that begin: "I dilate you with tremendous breath . . . . I buoy you up;" (1855, p. 45).

lg.l:
Buoyed with tremendous breath
shall you be, and dilated

I dilate you with tremendous
breath,—
I buoy you up,

Every room of your house do
I fill with armed men
Lovers of me, bafflers of hell,

Sleep! for I and they staynd
guard
all this night

Not doubt, not fear, not
Death shall lay finger
upon you

God and I have embraced you, and
henceforth possess you
all to
ourmyselves,

And when you rise in the
morning you shall find it
is so.—

note.p: These lines are similar to the following, from the poem that would be titled "There Was a Child": "The horizon's edge, the flying seacrow, the fragrance of saltmarsh and shoremud" (1855, p. 91).

lg.l:
And the odor of the
salt marsh is delicious perfume,
enough

And the salt marsh and creek have
a delicious odors,

And a potato and ears of
maize make a fat
breakfast, when need

And a handfull of huckleberrys from the woods
distill an a a joyous
deliriums
God and I are now here

Speak?! what would you
have of us?
I am the Poet

note.p: These four lines are a nearly word-for-word draft of the lines "Has any one supposed it lucky to be born? / I hasten to inform him or her it is just as lucky to die, and I know it. / I pass death with the dying, and birth with the new-washed babe . . . . and am not contained between my hat and boots" from the poem that would be titled "Song of Myself" (1855, p. 17).

lg.l:
Do Have you supposed it beautiful
to be born?

I tell you
I know it it is
more just as
beautiful to die;
For I take my death with the dying
And my birth with the new-born babes

note.p: Some of the words in these lines correspond to lines in the poem that would be titled "The Sleepers", including the line: "I WANDER all night in my vision, / Stepping with light feet . . . . swiftly and noiselessly stepping and stopping" (1855, p. 70).

lg.l: I am the poet of sin,
For I do not believe in sin
¶ In the silence of and darkness

Among murderers and cannibals
and traders in slaves

Stepped my soul spirit with
light feet, and pried among
them their heads and
drew in made fissures
in their breasts, to look through

And there
like saw folded fœtuses of twins

And not in a single one
there in every brain
of the earth

saw truth and sympathy
lay folded, like the fœtus of twins in the womb,
Mute with bent necks, Waiting to be born.—
And one was sympathy and one was truth.

note.p: These lines are a close draft of the lines that appear in the poem that would be titled "Song of Myself": "I am the poet of the woman the same as the man, / And I say it is as great to be a woman as to be a man" (1855, p. 26).

These lines are similar to the following lines from the poem that would be titled "A Song for Occupations": "The wife—and she is not one jot less than the husband, / The daughter—and she is just as good as the son, / The mother—and she is every bit as much as the father." (1855, p. 58).

lg.l:
I am the poet of women as well
as men.

The woman is not
the same less than the man as

But she is
not never
less the same,

I remember I stood one Sunday
forenoon,

note.p: These lines are similar to the following lines in the poem that would be titled "Song of Myself": "You there, impotent, loose in the knees, open your scarfed chops till I blow grit within you, / Spread your palms and lift the flaps of your pockets, / I am not to be denied . . . . I compel . . . . I have stores plenty and to spare, / And any thing I have I bestow." (1855, p. 44).

lg.head: Strength
lg.l:
Where is one abortive, mangy,
cold?
Starved of his masculine lustiness?

Weakened, Without core Loose in the knees,
without core? and grit and
and grit?

Clutch fast to me, my my
ungrown brother,

And That I will infuse you
with grit and jets of
new grit life
I will am not to be denied—I compel;

* I have stores plenty and
to spare—

And of whatsoever I have I
share bestow
fully with upon you.
And first I bestow of my love,

* It is quite indifferent to me
who you
are are.

It were easy to be rich
owning a dozen banks
But to be rich

It were easy to grant
offices and favors being
President

But to grand largess and
favor

It were easy to be
beautiful with a fine
complexion and regular
featursfeatures
But to beautiful

It were easy to be
shine and attract attention
in grand clothes

But to outshine ?
in sixpenny muslin

One touch of a tug of
me has
made unhaltered all
my other senses run
but feeling

That pleases the rest so,
they have given up to it f themselves

They are all emulous
to swap themselves
off for what it can do, to them,

wants to must be

Or
if that cannot be else,
they she will abdicate
and nibble only at
the edges of

over up and down my body

They
have left leave themselves
and

their store
to whatever their to whatever part of
me touches.—

Sometimes tTo my lips, and
and to the palms of
my hands, and whatever
my hands hold.

Each brings the best she
has,

For each is now in love
with touch.

Now I do not wonder
a touch now why that one feeling
now, or does so
much for me, now,

He is
recruited from free of all
the rest.—and improves
swiftly begets offspring of
them, better than the
dams.

A touch now shows me
how reads me a library of
knowledge delight
can be read in an
instant.
It shows me how

It smells for me the
fragrance of
roses wine and lemon-blows,

It tastes for me ripe
strawberries and
melons.—

It talks for me with
a tongue of its own,

It finds an ear wherever
it
taps or rests or taps,

It brings all the rest around it,
and to enjoy them and them awhile and then
and they all stand on a headland and
mock me

I am all given up by
traitors,

An I am myself the greatest
traitor.

All The sentries have deserted and the every
other part of home
but one,

I roam about drunk, and
stagger

They have left me to touch and gone taken to be
their place on a headland
the better to witness

They have left me helpless
to the torrent of touch
They have all come to the
I am given up by traitors,
I talk wildly I am surely out of my head,

I am myself the greatest
traitor.

For I went myself first
to the headland

Unloose me touch I can
stand it no longer you are taking the breath from my throat

Unbar your gates—I
can hold would keep you no
longer, for if I do you are too much for me.—
you will kill me
Pass out of me

Pass as you will
Gods! will

headland to witness and
assist against me.—

Fierce Wrestler! do you keep
your heaviest
strokes grip for
the last?

Gods! Wrestler!
wWill you sting
me most even at
parting?

Will you struggle even
at the
grthreshold with
gigantic delicious spasms
more delicious than all before?

Will you renew th
and

Does it make you ache
so to leave me?

W. Even as you fade
and withdraw

Do you wish to show me
that even what you
did before was nothing
to what you can do?

Or have you and all the
rest combined to see
how much I can
undergo

Pass as you will;
take drops of my
life, only go.
or is if that is
what you are
after

Only pass to some one
else, for I can
contain you no longer.
I held more than I thought

I did not think I was big
enough for so much exstasyecstasy

Or that a touch could
take it all out of me.

note.p: This passage is similar to excluded material from the poem that would be titled "The Sleepers." For further discussion, see Ed Folsom, "Walt Whitman's 'The Sleepers,'" Classroom Electric (www.classroomelectric.org).

lg.l: I am a Curse:

sSharper than wind serpent's
eyes or wind of the
ice-fields!

O topple down like Curse!
topple more heavy than
death!
I am lurid with rage!

I invoke Revenge to assist
me.—
I
A divine fa
Let fate pursue them

I do not know any horror
that is dreadful enough
for them—

What is the worst whip
you have

May the genitals—— that
begat them rot
May the womb that begat
I will not listen
I will not spare

They shall not hide themselves
in
grtheir graves

Out with them
fromcoffins—

Out with them from their
shrouds!

The lappets of God shall
not protect them

This shall be placed in the
library of the laws,

And they shall be placed in
the childs—doctors
—songwriters

note.p: This line echoes the following line in the poem that would be titled "Song of Myself": "I lean and loafe at my ease . . . . observing a spear of summer grass." (1855, p. 13). This passage contains identifications with Christ similar to those found in the following three lines from the poem: "That I could forget the mockers and insults! / That I could forget the trickling tears and the blows of the bludgeons and hammers! / That I could look with a separate look on my own crucifixion and bloody crowning!" (1855, p. 43).

Several lines in this passage may relate to a line from the poem that would later be titled "The Sleepers": "A shroud I see—and I am the shroud . . . . I wrap a body and lie in the coffin" (1855, p. 72).

add.l:
The sepulchre and the white
linen have yielded me
up

lg.l: Observing the summer grass

In vain were the nails driven through my
hands, and my head my
head mocked with a
prickly

I am here after I remember my
crucifixion and my
bloody coronation
The I remember the mockers and the buffeting insults

I am just as alive in
New York and San
Francisco, after two thousand
years.

Again I tread the streets after
two thousand years.

note.p: The discussion of churches and books in this section is reminiscent of the end of the poem that would be titled "Song of Occupations."

lg.l:
Not all the traditions can
put vitality in ch
built churches

They are not alive, they are
cold mortar and brick,

I
can easily can build as good, and so can
you.—

The bBooks are not men—
all the

note.p: This passage has language and ideas similar to the 1855 preface to Leaves of Grass (1855, p. vi).

lg.l:
In other authors of the first class
there have been celebraterscelebrators
of ? low life and characters
—holding it up as curious
observers—but here is
one who enters in it
with love

note.p: This line bears a noteworthy resemblance to the following line from the poem that would be titled "Song of Myself": "I think I could turn and live awhile with animals . . . . they are so placid and self-contained" (1855, p. 34). These lines may relate to the lines: "Houses and rooms are full of perfumes . . . . the shelves are crowded with perfumes, / I breathe the fragrance myself, and know it and like it, / The distillation would intoxicate me also, but I shall not let it." (1855, p. 13)

This line is similar to the following line, which appeared in the poem that would be titled "A Song for Occupations" (although by the time the poem was titled that, in the 1881 edition of Leaves of Grass, this line had been cut from it): "The snowstorm or rainstorm . . . . the tow-trowsers . . . . the lodge-hut in the woods, and the still-hunt: (1855, p. 62).
This passage anticipates Whitman's appreciation for "the open road" and seems to suggest his thinking toward "Song of the Open Road."

div2.ab:
It seems to say
sternly, Back
Do not leave me
—Loss—is an

note.p: These five lines appear in revised form in the poem "Song of Myself": "These are the thoughts of all men in all ages and lands, they are not original with me, / If they are not yours as much as mine they are nothing or next to nothing, / If they do not enclose everything they are next to nothing, / If they are not the riddle and the untying of the riddle they are nothing, / If they are not just as close as they are distant they are nothing." (1855, p. 24)

lg.l:
These are the thoughts of all
men in all ages and
lands—

They are not original with
me—they are mine
—they are yours just
the same

If these thoughts are not
for all they are
nothing

If they do not enclose
everything they are
nothing

If they are not the
school of all the
physical moral
and mental they are
nothing

note.p: This passage has ideas and language similar to the preface to the 1855 Leaves of Grass, in which Whitman discusses "the final test of poems" (1855, p. xi).

div2.ab: How far it can elevate, enlarge, purify deepen, and make happy the attributes of the body and soul of a man

note.p: This passage probably led to the following lines in the poem that would be titled "Great are the Myths": "Great is Justice;" through "They rule on the highest grounds . . . . they oversee all eras and states and administrations" (1855, p. 95). The poem went through many revisions through the different editions of Leaves of Grass, then was permanently dropped in 1881–1882, except the two couplets that became the poem "Youth, Day, Old Age, and Night."

div2.ab: * the people of this state shal instead of being ruled by the old complex laws, and the involved machinery of all governments hitherto, shall be ruled mainly by individual character and conviction.—The recognized character of the citizen shall be so pervaded by the best qualities of law and power that law and power shall be superseded from the government and transferred to the citizen

Justice
does not depend upon is not varied or tempered in the passage of an laws by legislatures.—The legislatures cannot
settle alter it any more than they can settle love or pride.—or the attraction of gravity. The quality of justice is in the soul.—It is immutable . . . . it remains through all times and nations and administrations . . . . it does not depend on majorities and and minorities . . . . Whoever violates it may shall fall pays the penalty just as certainly as he who violates the attraction
111
of gravity . . . . whether a nation violates it or an individual, it makes no difference.
div2.p: The test of justice is tThe consciousness of any individuals is the test of justice.—What is mean or cruel for an individual is so for a nation.

div2.ab: I am not so anxious to give you the truth,

But I am very anxious to
see have you understand that all truth and power are feeble to you except your own.—You Can I beget a child for you?

note.p: This line is similar to the following line in the poem that would be titled "Song of Myself": "This the common air that bathes the globe." (1855, p. 24). These lines are similar to the following lines in the poem: "This is the meal pleasantly set . . . . this is the meat and drink for natural hunger, / It is for the wicked just the same as the righteous . . . . I make appointments with all, / I will not have a single person slighted or left away, / The keptwoman and sponger and thief are hereby invited . . . . the heavy-lipped slave / is invited . . . . the venerealee is invited, / There shall be no difference between them and the rest." (1855, p. 25)

lg.l:
This is the common air . . . .
it is for the heroes
and sages . . . . it is for
the workingmen and
farmers . . . . it is for the
wicked just the same
as the righteous.

I will not have a single
person left out . . . . I
will have the prostitute and
the thief invited . . . . I
will make no difference
between them and the rest.

div2.ab: Let every thing be as free as possible.—There is always danger in constipation.—There is never danger in no constipation.—Let the schools and hospitals for the sick and idiots and the aged be perfectly free

No matter what stage of excellence and pr grandeur a nation has arrived to, it shall be but the start to further excellence and grandeur.—It shall enlarge the doors.—If it once settle down, placidly, content with what is, or with the past, it begins then to decay
Man has not art enough to make the truth repulsive—a nor of all the beautiful things of the universe is there any more beautiful than truth

In the earliest times (as we call them—though doubtless the term is wrong.) every thing written
allat all was poetry.—To write any how was a beautiful wonder.—Therefore history, laws, religion, war, were all in the keeping of the poet.—He was literature.—It was nothing but poems. Though a division and subdivision of subjects has for many centuries been made since then, it still prevails very much 115
as in those early times, so called.—Every thing yet is made the subject of poetry—narratives, descriptions, jokes, sermons, recipes, &c &c

note.p: The phrase "nation of nations" appearing in this passage is also used in the 1855 Preface to Leaves of Grass (1855, p. iii).

This section seems to relate to the following lines from the poem that would be titled "I Sing the Body Electric": "For him the globe lay preparing quintillions of years without one animal or plant, / For him the revolving cycles truly and steadily rolled" (1855, p. 81).

div2.ab: vast and tremendous is the scheme! It involves no less than constructing a state nation of nations—a state whose integral state whose grandeur and comprehensiveness of territory and people make the mightiest of the past almost insignificant—and

Could we imagine such a thing—let us suggest that before a manchild or womanchild was born it should be suggested that a human being could be born—imagine the world in its formation—the long rolling heaving cycles—can man appear here?—can the beautiful animal vegetable and animal life appear here?
